image.altText: man in yellow shirt and backpack

items.synopsis: Adil Abbas is the second food delivery worker to die in Sydney in the past month, prompting calls for reform of NSW's road rules.

title.children: 'We have to bury his dreams': Family mourn 19yo student killed while delivering food in Sydney

image.altText: Half underwater half sunset

items.synopsis: Climate scientists say natural "anaesthetics" have been masking the true impact of climate change for years but have now worn off. Here's why the world's ocean temperatures are at record highs and what they could bring.

title.children: There's a record-breaking heatwave in the sea. Here's why it's hit so hard, and what it means

image.altText: A close up of a man's face, his eyes look downwards. He is wearing a blue and red sports singlet.

items.synopsis: No professional male AFL player, past or present, has ever publicly come out as gay or bisexual. Insiders say a culture of homophobia lingers.

title.children: Michael's an out gay man who plays Aussie rules. Why isn't there anyone like him in the AFL?

image.altText: A man in a dark shirt in an office

items.synopsis: A former executive at one of the country's most disastrous share market floats in years says he wasn't surprised when the share price crashed, wiping billions of dollars from the fortunes of investors, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: 'Stuck with the rancid bacon': Insider lifts lid on the share market disaster that cost investors billions

image.altText: A team of soccer players wearing red and blue celebrates after winning a competition

items.synopsis: While they made history on Sunday night, Spain's first Women's World Cup title will always be haunted by the players who weren't there.

title.children: Spain's World Cup win lays bare the progress and problems of women's football

image.altText: Olga Carmona smiles with her World Cup winner's medal around her neck

items.synopsis: Just hours after a player-of-the-match performance in the Women's World Cup final, Spain captain Olga Carmona found out her father had died.

title.children: Spain World Cup hero Olga Carmona learns of father's death after final victory

image.altText: Rachel Daly, Keira Walsh and Lauren Hemp stand and look sad

items.synopsis: The scenes of heartache and despair are so familiar to fans of the England national team as to become almost inured to them. But this Lionesses team are different, writes Simon Smale.

title.children: Defeat for England's Lionesses has become entirely unexpected, even when it's deserved

image.altText: Woman lying in curled up position on couch.

items.synopsis: More than 50,000 people with endometriosis have helped map the impact of the condition around the country, as the federal opposition calls on the government to expand its new pelvic pain clinics.

title.children: Calls for endometriosis clinic expansion as research reveals major gaps

image.altText: PM Albanese waves to labor conference

items.synopsis: For a political party that makes a virtue of having its fights in the open, Labor's national conference didn't involve a whole lot of fighting. But that doesn't mean there aren't battles on the horizon, writes Tom Lowrey.

title.children: Albo 2032? What Labor's conference tells us about what a long-term Albanese government might look like

image.altText: A man standing among piles of rubbish in the bush.

items.synopsis: Piles of rubbish have been left in bushland on the NSW Central Coast after those living there were moved on.

title.children: Former homeless camp resembles 'landfill' near coast town's CBD

image.altText: planes on an airport runway

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Class action lodged against Qantas over COVID flight cancellations — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A class action has been lodged against Qantas on behalf of customers whose flights were cancelled during the COVID-19 pandemic. Legal firm Echo Law is bringing the Federal Court proceedings, saying the airline's failure to refund money when flights were cancelled, in accordance with its own conditions of carriage, was unlawful. They're also accusing Qantas of requiring customers to pay more than their original booking to use their credits on new fares.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Class action lodged against Qantas over COVID flight cancellations

children.content: A class action has been lodged against Qantas on behalf of customers whose flights were cancelled during the COVID-19 pandemic.

props.alt: A Qantas plane sits on the tarmac.

children.content: (ABC News: Natasha Johnson)

Legal firm Echo Law is bringing the Federal Court proceedings, saying the airline's failure to refund money when flights were cancelled, in accordance with its own conditions of carriage, was unlawful.
They're also accusing Qantas of requiring customers to pay more than their original booking to use their credits on new fares.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former US president Donald Trump has confirmed he will skip Wednesday’s first Republican presidential primary debate — and others as well. "The public knows who I am & what a successful Presidency I had," Trump says on his social media site. "I WILL THEREFORE NOT BE DOING THE DEBATES!" he wrote. The Associated Press says his spokesman has not clarified whether he plans to boycott every primary debate or just the currently scheduled ones. The former president and early GOP frontrunner has said for months he sees little upside in joining his rivals on stage when they gather for the first time in Milwaukee on Wednesday, given his commanding lead in the race.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump will skip first Republican presidential primary debate

props.alt: Donald trump in a maga hat

children.content: (Reuters: Alan Freed)
Former US president Donald Trump has confirmed he will skip Wednesday’s first Republican presidential primary debate — and others as well.
"The public knows who I am
what a successful Presidency I had," Trump says on his social media site.
"I WILL THEREFORE NOT BE DOING THE DEBATES!" he wrote.
The Associated Press says his spokesman has not clarified whether he plans to boycott every primary debate or just the currently scheduled ones.
The former president and early GOP frontrunner has said for months
he sees little upside in joining his rivals on stage when they gather for the first time in Milwaukee on Wednesday, given his commanding lead in the race.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Baja California Peninsula region in Mexico has been pelted with intense rain as tropical storm Hilary makes its way to the US. One person is dead in Mexico amid reports of flash flooding in the peninsula, where some roads were swept away and images on social media showed raging torrents gushing down city streets that have been turned into rivers. In the United States, the storm is already wreaking havoc on flights and sporting events before it's even arrived, and officials are warning residents to remain indoors and keep emergency supplies handy. Though Hilary has been weakening over the last 48 hours as it nears land, it is still set to be the wettest storm ever to hit the US Southwest, according to Zack Taylor, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service (NWS). "This is a dangerous storm," he says. "It's not just the rain totals but the intensity." Reuters is reporting that Hilary is set to dump vast amounts of water on many parts of the US Southwest that are more accustomed to dry conditions. Areas such as Palm Springs, California, which typically gets around 116 millimetres of rain in an entire year, could receive 152mm to 254mm from this one storm. California's Death Valley area, which receives only about 55 millimetres of rain per year, could receive 76-101 millimetres of rain from this event.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tropical storm Hilary makes landfall over Baja California peninsula

props.alt: A man walks in a rain poncho in Tijiuana

children.content: (Reuters: Aimee Melo)

Though Hilary has been weakening over the last 48 hours as it nears land, it is still set to be the
wettest storm ever

"This is a dangerous storm," he says.

image.altText: A fire burns over a hill. It is night,  and the sky is black with the fire and smoke red and orange.

image.altText: A teenage boy in a hat, vest and business shirt gestures while he conducts an auction.
